Therefore, in C, to implement this:

We need to:

- Convert the current i to a string.

- Process each character from the end to the beginning.

- Build the new string as per the rules.

- Check if the flag f was set; if not, append '3'.

- Reverse the new string to get the next number's digits in order.

- Convert that reversed string to a long (or integer, but since it can be up to N which could be big, but in C, perhaps using long long).

But in C, handling strings and digits can be done with arrays.

So steps for the transformation function in C:

Function to compute next_i from current_i:

char s[20]; // assuming i can be up to 1e18, but 20 chars should be enough.

sprintf(s, "%lld", current_i); // assuming current_i is a long long.

int len = strlen(s);

char new_s[20] = {0};

int f = 0;

int new_len = 0;

for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {

    char c = s[len - 1 - j]; // processing from the end.

    if (!f) {

        if (c == '3') {

            new_s[new_len++] = '5';

            f = 1;

        } else if (c == '5') {

            new_s[new_len++] = '7';

            f = 1;

        } else {

            new_s[new_len++] = '3';

        }

    } else {

        new_s[new_len++] = c;

    }

}

// After processing all characters, check if f is still 0 (no 3 or 5 found)

if (!f) {

    new_s[new_len++] = '3';

}

// Now, reverse new_s to get the next number's string.

char reversed[20];

int k;

for (k = 0; k < new_len; k++) {

    reversed[k] = new_s[new_len - 1 - k];

}

reversed[k] = '\0';

// Now, parse reversed to get next_i.

long long next_i = atoll(reversed);

return next_i;

    char new_s[20] = {0};

Putting it all together:

The full C program would be:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <limits.h>

int main() {
    int N;
    scanf("%d", &N);
    int arr[N];
    for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
        scanf("%d", &arr[i]);
    }

    int current_min = INT_MAX;
    int sum = 0;
    for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
        int prev_min = current_min;
        if (arr[i] < current_min) {
            current_min = arr[i];
        }
        if (arr[i] <= prev_min) {
            sum++;
        }
    }

    int N_second = sum;
    long long i = 357;
    int c = 0;
    while (i <= N_second) {
        char s[20];
        sprintf(s, "%lld", i);
        int has3 = 0, has5 = 0, has7 = 0;
        for (int k = 0; s[k]; k++) {
            if (s[k] == '3') has3 = 1;
            else if (s[k] == '5') has5 = 1;
            else if (s[k] == '7') has7 = 1;
        }
        if (has3 && has5 && has7) {
            c++;
        }

        // Compute next i
        char s_i[20];
        sprintf(s_i, "%lld", i);
        int len = strlen(s_i);
        char new_s[20] = {0};
        int f = 0;
        int new_len = 0;
        for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
            char c_char = s_i[len - 1 - j];
            if (!f) {
                if (c_char == '3') {
                    new_s[new_len++] = '5';
                    f = 1;
                } else if (c_char == '5') {
                    new_s[new_len++] = '7';
                    f = 1;
                } else {
                    new_s[new_len++] = '3';
                }
            } else {
                new_s[new_len++] = c_char;
            }
        }
        if (!f) {
            new_s[new_len++] = '3';
        }

        char reversed[20];
        for (int k = 0; k < new_len; k++) {
            reversed[k] = new_s[new_len - 1 - k];
        }
        reversed[new_len] = '\0';
        i = atoll(reversed);
    }

    printf("%d\n", c);
    return 0;
}

Wait, but in the transformation part, when building new_s, the loop for j runs from 0 to len-1. For each j, the character is s_i[len-1-j], which is correct.

Also, when reversing, the reversed array must be null-terminated. The code sets reversed[new_len] = '\0', but the loop runs for k from 0 to new_len-1, so reversed[k] for k < new_len, then the null terminator is at new_len.

Wait, in the code:

for (int k=0; k < new_len; k++) {

    reversed[k] = new_s[new_len -1 -k];

}

reversed[new_len] = '\0';

Potential issues:

- Handling very large numbers in the transformation. For example, if N_second is very large (like 1e18), the string conversion and parsing may have issues, but using long long and atoll should handle it.

- The array size for arr: in C, variable-length arrays are allowed in C99, but if the input N is very large, it might cause stack overflow. However, given the problem's context, it's probably acceptable.

- The second part's loop may have an infinite loop if the transformation doesn't increase i properly. But according to the Java code's logic, the transformation should generate numbers in increasing order, so the loop will terminate when i exceeds N_second.

Another possible issue is when the transformation produces a number larger than N_second, but the loop condition is i <= N_second, so it will stop.

Thus, this should work.
